data.title: Better documentation for Disposables
data.body:
One of the most common issues I've noticed with Atom packages is they fail to dispose their Disposables. This causes a whole load of problems with callbacks being registered multiple times when updating packages (or disabling and re-enabling them). Updating packages to fix issues often doesn't work because the old, broken callbacks stick around until you restart Atom.

The package development documentation hasn't really been updated since Disposables were introduced. [Your First Package](https://atom.io/docs/v0.169.0/your-first-package) and the [ascii-art package](https://github.com/atom/ascii-art/blob/master/lib/ascii-art.coffee) show how to register commands, but don't hold on to the Disposable, and don't call `dispose` in the `deactivate` method:

``` coffee
atom.workspaceView.command "ascii-art:convert", => @convert()
```

A few examples of popular packages not behaving properly:
### emmet

https://github.com/emmetio/emmet-atom/blob/60ad28616defddc8fb8746476717cc726b53b15b/lib/emmet.coffee#L117
### linter

https://github.com/AtomLinter/Linter/blob/eff2c313efc240aca8d4bc3f9b7dc811988c8bd4/lib/linter-view.coffee#L94
https://github.com/AtomLinter/Linter/blob/eff2c313efc240aca8d4bc3f9b7dc811988c8bd4/lib/linter-view.coffee#L116
### color-picker

https://github.com/thomaslindstrom/color-picker/blob/e9b64487f827223ca9ec0479f7075db48b43f02d/lib/ColorPicker.coffee#L18
### atomatigit

https://github.com/diiq/atomatigit/blob/d521a615517e4e0643987cc4e02fd3a307205be0/lib/atomatigit.coffee#L43

So package developers often have no idea they're missing something. I think this is unfortunately contributing to a negative image - while Atom's core packages are great, users are bound to associate the problems caused by third party packages with Atom itself.

It needs to be made more explicit that when you register commands or other callbacks, you need to hold on to the Disposable, and you need to dispose it properly when you're done with it.

data.title: New settings toggle switch style is non-obvious, especially for colorblind users and maybe in some cultures
data.body:
The new toggle switch style of checkbox strikes me as fairly ambiguous:
- Gray-vs-green excludes many colorblind people. (See image.)
- The icons _also_ look like horizontal traffic lights. In Japan, notably, the _rightmost_ light in a horizontal traffic light is the one that's red.

Despite being neither colorblind nor from a country with right-to-left traffic lights, I'd nonetheless appreciate a little more visual distinction between the two states of these switches.

![grey-checkboxes](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1090235/5672481/8476612c-9745-11e4-9993-55c3d6ba3d9e.png)

[Reported on v0.169, running on OS X.]

data.title: Error Installing Atom Package on Windows 8.1
data.body:
After insuring that Atom can find Git (see Atom issue #4902, which resulted in success for Windows 7), the installation of a package is running into an error later in the process. The log says to open an issue for npm (npm issue # 7100), but there I was advised that Atom bundles an older version of npm that is no longer supported and that the error should be reported here.

data.title: Add color support to config schema
data.body:
This adds first-class support for colors in the config schema.

``` coffee
atom.config.set('my-package.aColor', 'khaki')
atom.config.get('my-package.aColor') # {red: 240, green: 230, blue: 140, alpha: 1}
atom.config.get('my-package.aColor').toHexString() # '#f0e68c'
atom.config.get('my-package.aColor').toRGBAString() # 'rgba(240, 230, 140, 1)'

atom.config.set('my-package.bColor', 'rgba(10,20, 30, .75)')
atom.config.get('my-package.bColor') # {red: 10, green: 20, blue: 30, alpha: .75}
```

This will be used to make themes adjustable by allowing colors to be changed in the settings view and those color changes will be reflected in Less variables in the loaded theme stylesheets.

data.title: "ctrl-," keybinding only works if you hold it down (Ubuntu Linux)
data.body:
**System**: Ubuntu 14.04.1 LTS
**Atom:** 0.169.0

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Assign the keybinding `'ctrl-,'` to any command you want or leave it set to `settings-view:open`
2. Try entering the shortcut as you would any other keyboard shortcut. Nothing should happen.
3. Try entering the shortcut repeatedly. Nothing should happen.
4. Hold down the shortcut until the command executes.

This is definitely not a Mac issue, as I've never encountered it on my Mac running Yosemite - just on Ubuntu.

data.title: Return & Tab Keys no longer work at random
data.body:
After updating to `0.169.0` I find that, seemingly at random, the Return and Tab keys on my MacBook Pro no longer work. Pressing them will just do nothing, and the only way to regain functionality is to completely quit atom and restart it, but even then it seems that it's only a matter of time before they stop working again.

Didn't see this at all before the update. No clues as to what's going on either.

data.title: After 0.168 not able to press enter in any file
data.body:
Enter does nothing.
**_Alt-enter**_ is needed to make a new line.
Also just updated to 169 and it persists. 
So far happening in both .haml files, ruby and js files.

data.title: Opening a directory on startup doesn't restore the project state
data.body:
I'm running on OS X.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Start Atom
2. Open a directory
3. Open a file so there's a tab open
4. Restart Atom
5. Reopen the same directory

I expect the workspace to be restored (i.e. the file should be opened) when I reopen the directory in Atom. If I open the directory a second time after startup, it does the proper thing (but then I have two workspaces open that are backed by the same directory/project).

data.title: How do you listen for an event from inside the shadow dom?
data.body:
I'm sorry if this is a stupid question but I'm stuck.  I need to respond to a click on a line-number inside the `atom-text-editor` and I can't figure out how to do it.  The dom shadow gets in my way for everything I try.  

A simple `$('.line-number')` gets zero matches when the dom shadow is enabled.  I can match on the `atom-text-editor` element but nothing inside.  I read the package update doc and it just refers to `$(window)` which doesn't help.

This is a bit of a duplicate from .https://discuss.atom.io/t/events-from-elements-inside-shadow-dom/14119.

data.title: Use special compile cache when sudo-ing as root
data.body:
Create a special compile cache for when sudo'ing as root so file permissions don't get messed up when folders are created by root and then written to by another user.

Closes #3082

data.title: Better errors
data.body:
- When someone does not have access, opens a large file, or opens a bad file, it will have a nice error.
  ![screen shot 2015-01-08 at 5 18 45 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/69169/5674126/6e4d7524-975a-11e4-8cc9-978e7f50b725.png)
  - Closes #4421 
- When there is an error reading the file after getting a file changed event, it will have a better error. 
  ![screen shot 2015-01-08 at 5 12 52 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/69169/5674088/03726e6c-975a-11e4-8bf8-782d71cf51f6.png)
  - Relies on https://github.com/atom/text-buffer/pull/41 and https://github.com/atom/node-pathwatcher/pull/54
  - Closes #4850 
  - Closes #4751 
  - Closes #4639 
  - Closes #4576 
- When there is a problem opening / watching config, keymaps, snippets, we display a better error.
  - Closes atom/snippets#97
### TODO
- [x] Open access errors
- [x] Errors on read after file change event
- [x] `unable to watch path` errors for config, keymap, user scripts on startup
- [x] Make sure the bad-config errors arent crazy
